comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: We're right at the junction with Shop St. to the left, St. Mary's Bridge to the right. Google Streetview shows the quayside quite changed, but the roofline to the left is still similar. The OS 25" shows the Hotel to the left, survey date June 1907.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]  I'd agree that it is the "Kyne" and the next one down has three letters visible "S or GIF?".  What a beauty of a shot, for those of us who know the place it has changed very little but look at those ships???  Fantastic detail and imagery.  They are all moored about 10 to 15 feet from the quay wall, obviously because the bottom sloped up rapidly, and there is a plank across that considerable gap.  Talk about walking the plank.  You will also note that each ship has a dinghy beside the gangway for the less than nimble to come and go?  Look at the length of that roofers ladder on the left?  Imagine carrying that around on your shoulder or on your bicycle as they used to do? Brilliant shot Carol, well done.  Did you take it yourself?

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: The symmetrey in this photo is spectacular. That wall would not have been very conducive to cargo handling. I wonder if that was a holding area for the ships between voyages?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] Thats a good point given the distance they are from the wall as well.  There is also a lack of space for manoeuvreing drays etc. on the quayside.  You can see another ship in the background either getting ready to dock or to leave and judging by the tiny bow wave the tide is flowing so it may be leaving.  It is possible that there was a small jetty or dock over on the Scotch Hall side where actual unloading was done, unless of course these were passenger ships taking emigrants to far away places?  The 1860's were a time of mass emigration from Ireland and all of the ports were handling such ships.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The chap nearest the camera is wearing a bowler hat but they were invented in 1844 so that is no help to us date wise!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Interested in the terrific Boyne Viaduct - "It was the seventh bridge of its kind in the world when built and considered one of the wonders of the age." 157 years old. YouTube video of steam train on the viaduct

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Merchant's Quay further down did not have a wall.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That looks more like it for cargo.  There's no sign of land based cranes or derricks so they must have been using a spar and tackle on the ships themselves to unload whatever they were carrying.  Incidentally I note in the youtube video posted by Beachcomber that there is a Martin Butterly has a warehouse on the quay near the viaduct, continuing the name on the shop on the left of this shot.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Gaslight dates, no help: It had been strictly gas driven before that, Ned McHugh's history of the post stating that a gas works was established on North Quay in 1821 for street lighting. It later moved to the Marsh Road, beside the Chemical Manure factory and was bought by the Corporation in 1898 More here: The company started as early as 1826 when it acquired the old Gas Works, when the latter moved across 'the river to the Marsh Road,

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Excellent, the chap on the roof is particularly interesting! Railway viaduct, then fairly new, in its original condition before rebuilding many years later.

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content:
The ladder that the roofer used to access the roof looks like a type of a Wheeled Escape Ladder. A 50ft ladder with wheels
Wheeled Escape Ladders were carried on fire engines in the UK until the 1970s. In Victorian times before fire engines were built that could carry a wheeled escape. the ladders were kept at strategic points in the city or town. If they were needed for a rescue they were wheeled to the incident by the firemen and whatever volunteers they could muster to push it.  Perhaps there was one in Drogheda and the roofer took advantage of it.?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/crexcrex] Its hard to tell with the DOF in this shot but there doesn't seem to be any wheels for that ladder in evidence.  The two sets of wheels nearest it are on the two donkey carts.  Did those wheels detach when the ladder arrived where it was needed?

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: Yes I have to agree. i had a look with a 'glass' and I can now see that it's a donkey cart. Never mind...at least we all learnt a bit about 'wheeled escape ladders' and in answer to the question the wheels of the ladder do not detach flic.kr/p/9ksrWp
